Topic.Title: BAC is boring? Buy VRNG!

Message.Msg: I did some DD on that one. VRNG won a jury civil suit against GOOG. The basis of the suit is a patent created by Ken Lang formerly of Lycos from the early 90's. Mr. Lang is now a chief Technology officer of VRNG,IP/protect. Surprisngly GOOG does not own the necessary patents for Adworks/Adaware and they get 85% of their revenues from this technology that allows for targeted advertisements on the web. VRNG owns that patent but the jury award for prior infringement was rather small 30 million with a 3.5% royalty rate running for another 3 years when the original LYCOS patent expires. The judge in the case is going to provide a final ruling on the case and it is possible he may increase the royalty based onthe premise of ongoing wilful infringement. But MSFT just settled with VRNG and as part of the settlement VRNG received 6 patents related to telecom. It seems that the basis of the company is to seek out licensing agreements or obtain jury awards based on a large and growing portfolio of patents. Basically you are buying into a plaintiff law firm - but a very good one. At the current market cap that could pay off big like VHC paid off. VRNG attorneys know what they are doing. Background, the company VRNG was primarily a ring-tone creator taken over in a "reverse-merger" by IP/Protect. Also, BAC is the investment of the decade.

Message.Title: Bank Of America A Buy.
Message.Msg: Recent Increases In Bond Yields, Housing Prices, And Home Sales Make Bank Of America A Buy Disclosure: I have no positions in any stocks mentioned, but may initiate a long position in BAC over the next 72 hours. Banks profit from lending out money and/or making deals involving lending such as securitizing loans. In this way, other people effectively buy the loans yet the banks make a profit. Banks also invest capital (even loans are an investment). This means their profits are very sensitive to the net interest margin (the difference between the cost of funds for the banks and the amount of money the bank earns on those funds). When the net interest margin is wider, banks make more money.

Topic.Title: Bank Of America A Buy.

Message.Msg: All of that is true, but banks also borrow money, lots of it, and they have to pay interest on deposits. As interest rates rise, so does the cost to banks. In addition, as interest rates rise, the value of older low interest rate loans on the books, such as mortgage loans, decrease in value. They key is for the interest rates at which banks loan to rise faster than the interest rates on funds the banks have to borrow or what they have to pay on deposits. As long as rates rise at an easy pace, things will be okay. If, however, things get out of hand, like they did in the 70's, things will not be so joyous.

Topic.Title: Here's a Thought.

Message.Msg: Everyone miscalculated and forgot even the basics of market forces. The doom and gloomers figured the down cycle would never end and the pie in the sky optimists thought all the problems would just disappear in the whiff of a dream. The real truth is what's occurring now. The issues are being dealt with, slowly but surely. Even BAC is digging out from their pit, just as many of us have said all along. The housing market is improving, slowly. The fact that people simply stopped selling their homes took everyone by surprise for some reason. Simple economics would have told anyone that people wouldn't sell if they couldn't get the price they needed or wanted. People worried about the overhang of foreclosures and bank owned property, but failed to listen to the news that many of those properties were being bought up in huge blocks by investor groups and being turned into rental properties. Now the news tells us that house flippers are back again. That doesn't speak of a weak market. People will see what they want to see and hear what they want to hear. The truth is, when given enough time, the markets will correct themselves, and despite the best efforts of government to keep it from happening, that's exactly what's taking place.

Message.Title: ( NEOM )Neomedia Technologies a Worldwide Pioneer Leader in Q R Codes is Poised to Surge Again
Message.Msg: NeoReader, the barcode scanning app, experienced continued growth in 2012 because of increased mobile barcode adoption, with more than 34 million installations worldwide. NeoMedia has generated more than 79,000 mobile barcodes and QR codes and generated scan activity from 193 countries, with the top three being the United States, Spain and Germany.NeoMedia also added eight new companies to its list of IP licensees.Over the past year, NeoMedia was able to realign its operations and business strategy to meet the changing needs of today's digital marketer and mobile application developer, according to a press statement. The company increased its agreements for its 2-D Core products while reducing the focus on its hardware product sales."By aligning our business more closely to the needs of our customers and the market, we have been able to reach self sustainability from cash received during the year," said Laura Marriott, NeoMedia's chief executive, in the press statement. "We look forward to further helping brands get closer to their customers with our mobile barcode solutions."NeoMedia's current customers include international brands, agencies and handset manufacturers. The company also has a growing portfolio of patent licensees including Microsoft Corp. and Kraft Foods Group Inc.

Topic.Title: typical 3:30pm dump

Message.Msg: It's a game in which you either learn the rules and play by them or you make your own rules. Most small investors are ill equipped to play this game mostly because they either have some wild eyed idea of how things should be done in a perfect world, and they gamble with money they can ill afford to lose, believing they will get rich. Well, this isn't a perfect world, and the first rule of the game is never gamble with money you can't afford to lose. From there on it's a matter of watching and learning how the game is played and what the big boys are doing. Second rule of the game is never, ever take investing or trading advice from posters on these message board. Most don't have a clue what a stock is and most have no skin in the game despite all the fantastic claims they make.

Topic.Title: typical 3:30pm dump

Message.Msg: Mike: Part of trading. Learn to live with the fluctuations,..a given in this market. Be sure you do not have a broker that trades AGAINST you by "stop hunting". Some do that. Keep studying this market and you will soon see the manipulation. It is a big problem we must learn to "play". BAC is very strong, getting stronger, so don't worry too much about BAC. It's the lesser priced stocks that are dangerous. Many pumps and dumps. Be careful of these, GL.
